author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: A Glut of Chinese Masks Is Driving U.S. Companies Out of Business
description: Remember when N95s were in short supply? American companies stepped in to manufacture them. Now, they can’t compete.
content: Mask mandates have eased, a welcome milestone in the battle against Covid-19. But for the two dozen domestic companies that jumped into the mask-making business last year, the good news comes with a downside: a calamitous drop in sales.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Chelsea wins the Champions League, its chaos conquering City’s plan.
description: Chelsea won the Champions League for the second time, defeating Manchester City in a battle for control of European soccer’s biggest prize.
content: PORTO, Portugal — Manchester City’s players did not seem to want to leave. Not right away, at least. They stood, as if frozen in place, as Chelsea’s players heaved the prize City craves more than any other into the air. They could not go. To go, after all, would be to accept that it was real, that it was over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Cops Don’t Belong at Pride
description: Modern Pride celebrations began with a rebellion against the police. We have not forgotten that.
content: My wife, Debbie, came out as a lesbian when she was 50 years old. Her first Pride parade in New York City was also the first time, she told me early in our courtship, that she was able to understand what it feels like to be proud. There is a picture of her on Christopher Street, beaming. She is wearing a T-shirt that says, “Yep, I’m Gay.” Around her are hundreds of people from the L.G.B.T.Q. community, and allies, celebrating our right to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: ‘What Do I Do Next?’: Orphaned by Covid, Two Teens Find Their Way
description: The virus took their mother. Now, as the city reopens, a brother and a sister are rebuilding their lives.
content: Their mother went into cardiac arrest just before midnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Here’s how holiday-weekend travel in the U.S. will be different from 2020.
description: Many more people are likely to leave town for the Memorial Day holiday this year, meaning travelers facing crowded airports and roads.
content: Memorial Day weekend is underway in the United States, and things are decidedly different for travelers than they were a year ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: After Erdogan Angers a Loyal Province, His Opponents See an Opportunity
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey set off protests in his home province, the heart of his political base, with plans to build a quarry that would destroy a pristine woodland.
content: IKIZDERE, Turkey — Villagers in the pristine woodlands of Rize Province in northeastern Turkey have always had two natural advantages: a largely unspoiled landscape, rich in wildlife and trout-filled streams and the protective influence of the region’s most popular and powerful local citizen, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: They Call It ‘Insane’: Where Myanmar Sends Political Prisoners
description: For 134 years, Insein Prison has stood as a monument to brutality. Since the Feb. 1 coup, journalists, elected leaders and pro-democracy protesters have been held in the aging facility.
content: The prison was already packed, its population more than double its 5,000-person capacity. Recent prisoners include two American journalists and an Australian economic adviser. Hundreds of pro-democracy protesters have also been crammed in, some with fresh gunshot wounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Foster Friess, Big Donor to Republicans, Dies at 81
description: A conservative Christian and wealthy businessman, he gave millions to Rick Santorum and Donald Trump in their presidential bids.
content: Foster Friess, a Wyoming businessman who founded an investment firm, made a fortune and gave a lot of it away to Republican presidential candidates and charities, sometimes with flair, died on Thursday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

title: J. Cole, Triumphant (at His Own Pace)
description: The rapper’s sixth No. 1 album is here. Listen to a conversation about his career, and the long exchange between hip-hop and basketball.
content: Of hip-hop’s current superstar elite, no one has had a path to the top as curious or unexpected as J. Cole. A decade ago, he had his eye on becoming one of rap’s biggest stars in the mold of Jay-Z and Nas. But when he found the path to the top riddled with compromises, he peeled off to follow his own happiness, resulting in some of the most popular and successful music of his career. He just released his sixth album, “The Off-Season,” which debuted at the top of the Billboard album chart, just like the five that preceded it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Before She Was C.E.O., She Cleaned Toilets. ‘How Wonderful Is That?’
description: Beth Ford has spent much of her career working on supply chain issues, which has served her well as the leader of Land O’ Lakes.
content: When Land O’ Lakes redesigned its packaging last year to remove a decades-old illustration of a Native America woman, it seemed like just another dust-up in the culture wars. Liberal activists and politicians praised the company for abandoning stereotypical imagery. The conservative National Review ran a story titled “Land O’Lakes Cancels Its Century-Old Native American ‘Butter Maiden.’” Some customers boycotted the company for its “virtue signaling.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Is the final Christian Pulisic’s big moment?
description: The American midfielder helped deliver Chelsea to the Champions League final. But how much will he play in the game that matters most?
content: There is an American at today’s game. Two actually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: How ‘Friends’ Helps People Around the World Learn English
description: Language teachers say the show is a near-perfect amalgam of easy-to-understand English and real-life scenarios that feel familiar even to people who live worlds away from the West Village.
content: True or false: In the television show “Friends,” Monica Geller was invited to Rachel Green’s wedding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: ‘I Knew That I Couldn’t Stay Quiet’
description: Millions of Americans took part in street demonstrations after the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis. A year later, first-time protesters reflect on what happened — and what is next.
content: Last summer, millions of Americans took to the streets after the killing of George Floyd at the hands of the Minneapolis police, taking part in what would become the largest protest movement in U.S. history. Many participated in marches and demonstrations for the first time in their lives. From eight first-time protesters, here are reflections on what they did last summer, how this has affected them in the year since and what lies ahead. Their interviews have been edited and condensed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Thomas Sullivan Dies at 91; Investigated Corruption in Chicago’s Courts
description: He helped start an undercover sting that led to the convictions of judges, lawyers and sheriffs. He also worked on other high-profile cases as a defense lawyer.
content: Thomas Sullivan, a prominent defense lawyer in Chicago who, during his brief time as a federal prosecutor, helped initiate an extensive undercover investigation of corruption within the county court system that led to the convictions of judges, lawyers and sheriffs, died on May 18 at his home in Wilmette, Ill., outside Chicago. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wasn’t this game supposed to be in Turkey?
description: The short answer to that question above is: yes. The reasons are more complicated and, like so many things these day, all related to the coronavirus.
content: The short answer to that question above is: yes. The reasons are more complicated and, like so many things these day, all related to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 French Open: What to Watch on Sunday Morning
description: Opening round matches feature Naomi Osaka and Dominic Thiem, who are both pursuing their first French Open title.
content: How to watch: 5 a.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern time on the Tennis Channel and noon to 3 p.m. on Peacock; streaming on the Tennis Channel+ and Peacock apps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Daniel Politi and Santi Carneri
title: ‘Like a Dream’: Latin Americans Head to U.S. for Covid Shots
description: Frustrated with the lagging pace of vaccinations at home, well-off Latin Americans have been flying north for a shot — and feeling guilty about those left behind.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Florencia Gonzalez Alzaga, a photographer from Buenos Aires, hatched her plan to fly to the United States for a coronavirus vaccine after the subject came up in her Zoom book club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Zimbabwe Authorities Arrest Local Reporter Working for The New York Times
description: Jeffrey Moyo, a freelance journalist for The Times who is based in Harare, was being held on charges of violating the country’s immigration laws. His lawyers say the accusation is spurious.
content: The authorities in Zimbabwe have arrested a freelance reporter who works for The New York Times and accused him of improperly helping two other Times journalists make a reporting trip there recently, his lawyers said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Our Digital Pasts Weren’t Supposed to Be Weaponized Like This
description: A recent firing at The Associated Press is the latest example of the way in which our digital pasts are never far from the present, despite what early internet evangelists thought.
content: The internet is a fossil machine. It preserves our thoughts, our political positions, our jokes, our photos, our triumphs and our mistakes in silicon amber, just waiting to be dug up. And that has led to a kind of modern sport: Find an outrageous piece of a person’s past that can be weaponized, put it on display for all to see and hope for the worst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rowan Moore Gerety
title: The Way of the Conscientious Objector
description: A philosophical and moral conversion led this soldier to leave the military. Why don't more take this path?
content: It was a book of Buddhist parables that put Michael Rasmussen over the edge. In March 2017, Mr. Rasmussen was living near a naval base in Japan, six years into training as a Marine pilot, reading and experimenting with meditation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Summertime … and the Sloganeering Is a Little Awkward
description: Cities and states are spending millions to promote tourism as they reopen, but the marketing campaigns aren’t always the catchiest.
content: They are the opening lines of a reopening: entreaties by cities, states and nations seeking to draw a wary public by evoking a sense of togetherness, normalcy and — lest anyone forget — fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Is the Montauk Party Over?
description: Dive bars are out. Fine dining is in. Summer shares are scarce. Town leaders are hoping to put the kibosh on the antics of seasons past.
content: Before 2020, it was impossible to miss a wooden beach bar in Montauk called the Sloppy Tuna. Shoes and shirts were optional. Bikini-clad ladies and shirtless men would guzzle piña coladas on the deck. It was involved in numerous drug arrests and noise complaints.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The police have made a list and are checking it twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Hong Kong exempts corporate executives from its strict quarantine rules, and other news from around the world.
description: Fully vaccinated “senior executives” can ask to skip compulsory hotel stays. It’s not the first time that the city has applied its rules differently to certain segments of society.
content: Hong Kong’s borders have been sealed for more than a year and its quarantine rules — which require compulsory hotel stays of up to three weeks — are among the strictest in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: An Arms Race in America: Gun Buying Spiked During the Pandemic. It’s Still Up.
description: Preliminary research data show that about a fifth of all Americans who bought guns last year were first-time gun owners. Sales usually spike around elections, but the sheer volume is notable.
content: WASHINGTON — It was another week with another horrific mass shooting. In cities across the country, gun homicides were climbing. Democrats and Republicans argued over the causes. President Biden said enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Texas Republicans Finalize One of the Nation’s Strictest Voting Bills
description: The bill, which would make already stringent voting rules in Texas even tougher, is likely to pass both chambers of the Legislature. Gov. Greg Abbott is expected to sign it.
content: Texas lawmakers on Saturday finished drafting a bill that would impose a raft of new voting restrictions, setting up the likely passage of what would be among the most far-reaching laws in Republicans’ nationwide drive to overhaul elections systems and limit voting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Gina Kolata
title: Vietnam says it has detected a more contagious hybrid of variants first seen in India and Britain.
description: The country’s health minister cited lab evidence in discussing the transmissibility of the newly identified variant, but much remains unclear about its prevalence and perils.
content: Vietnam has discovered a new variant of the coronavirus that the country’s health minister said was a mix of the variants first detected in India and Britain and was also more contagious, according to news reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin and Hallie Golden
title: Island Residents Protest at the Willows Inn After Workplace Allegations
description: About 50 people carried signs and shouted ‘shame’ at diners Friday, after a New York Times article chronicled harassment and discrimination claims from former employees.
content: LUMMI ISLAND, Wash. — Carrying hand-painted signs with slogans like “Take Sexism Off the Menu!” and “Racism is NOT a Local Ingredient,” about 50 protesters gathered Friday night outside the Willows Inn, a world-renowned restaurant on this tiny island near the Canadian border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Patchwork
description: Crafty Eric Berlin brings us another fun word-weaving project.
content: PATCHWORK — Intertwining sets of entries, like Eric Berlin has done recently with new types of variety puzzles, is really so impressive; every time I solve one, I can’t imagine how it gets constructed. I can see getting better at it with practice, but I’ll forever be amazed by the different ways a solid block of letters can be split into two unique layers (compare today’s puzzle to last year’s “Cascades,” for example — very different solves).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Ex-Priest Dies Just Before Facing Charges in 1972 Killing of an Altar Boy
description: The police had long believed Richard R. Lavigne killed Danny Croteau, 13. Just hours after they began drafting a request for an arrest warrant, investigators learned that the former priest had died.
content: Nearly 50 years ago, the body of Danny Croteau, a 13-year-old altar boy, was found floating in the Chicopee River in Springfield, Mass. His head had been beaten with a blunt object.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: N.Y.C. Roads Are Busy Again, and So Are Traffic Reporters
description: In New York City, traffic has roared back to nearly prepandemic levels; perhaps no one has a better front-row seat than traffic reporters.
content: Buzzing over New York City in a traffic helicopter on a morning in March of last year, Tom Kaminski, a radio traffic reporter for more than three decades, looked down at the rush hour commute. He gasped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: A Witness to the Tulsa Massacre, and a Family History Forever Altered
description: Mary E. Jones Parrish was a journalist who chronicled the Tulsa Massacre. Her story of survival began with six words: “Mother, I see men with guns.”
content: Anneliese M. Bruner was in her mid-30s when her father presented her with a small red book. It was bound in cloth and worn at the corners. “This is a book your grandmother wrote,” he told her, “and I want you to see what you can do with it. You are the matriarch of the family now, and I’m giving this to you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: Wimar Witoelar, Puckish Spokesman for Indonesian President, Dies at 75
description: As a college student, he was briefly imprisoned for his activism. He later served President Abdurrahman Wahid and had a thriving career as a media figure.
content: Wimar Witoelar, a columnist, talk-show host, business consultant and political activist who served as media spokesman for the former Indonesian president Abdurrahman Wahid and brought a colorful presence to public life, died on May 19 at a hospital in South Jakarta. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Audra D. S. Burch
title: Anniversary Event for Tulsa Race Massacre Unraveled Over Reparations
description: A centennial commission that raised $30 million for a history exhibit center said the government should be responsible for repaying survivors and their descendants.
content: In a weekend of events commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Tulsa Race Massacre, one scheduled for Memorial Day at the city’s minor league baseball stadium was to have been a main attraction. It was to be televised, with John Legend performing, and Stacey Abrams giving the keynote speech before thousands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Just in Time for Pool Season: A Chlorine Shortage
description: A fire at a chemical plant and a pandemic-driven boom in the construction of backyard pools are the causes of a nationwide shortage of chlorine tablets, experts say. Panic buying could make it worse.
content: Stuck at home because of the coronavirus pandemic, people who found themselves sitting on savings from canceled vacations and other cutbacks built pools in record numbers last year to make quarantine more enjoyable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: The D.N.C. Didn’t Get Hacked in 2020. Here’s Why.
description: A devastating email breach of the D.N.C. roiled Democrats in the final months of 2016. An unassuming security official made it his mission to prevent a recurrence.
content: As the country learns more about a broad Russian hijacking of American federal agencies and private companies and now another Russian hack, which was revealed on Thursday, it can look to the Democratic National Committee for a more positive development in the effort to prevent cyberattacks: Unlike four years ago, the committee did not get hacked in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Sister Margherita Marchione, Defender of Pius XII, Dies at 99
description: She spent decades arguing that the pope had helped the Jews during World War II, despite accusations that he had abdicated his moral responsibility.
content: Sister Margherita Marchione, who became known as “the fighting nun” for her defense of Pope Pius XII against allegations that he had failed to do as much as he could have to save the Jews from Nazi atrocities during World War II, died on May 19 at her convent, Villa Walsh, in Morristown, N.J. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: U.S. to Reimpose Sanctions on Belarus Over Forced Plane Landing
description: The move is the latest Western response to the forced landing of a European commercial flight with a Belarusian dissident aboard.
content: The Biden administration said late Friday that it would reimpose economic sanctions on certain state-owned companies in Belarus, the latest diplomatic pushback from a Western government after the country’s authoritarian leader forced down a European passenger jet last weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elinor Lipman
title: Welcome to the Party of the Century. Leave Your Scruples at the Door.
description: In “Malibu Rising,” Taylor Jenkins Reid surfs a wave of fame, dysfunction and sibling forbearance.
content: MALIBU RISINGBy Taylor Jenkins Reid
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas St. Fleur
title: Manhattanhenge 2021: When and Where to Watch
description: Saturday will bring New Yorkers their first shot at “the best sunset picture of the year.” Sunday and two days in July will provide more opportunities.
content: For two days every spring and summer, the sunset lines up with Manhattan’s street grid, creating a gorgeous celestial spectacle. For a brief moment, the sun’s golden rays illuminate the city’s buildings and traffic with a breathtaking glow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why the Lab Leak Theory Matters
description: The debate about Covid’s origins will have implications beyond the media critique.
content: On Long Bets, a website where prognosticators test their mettle by playing for real (or at least proceeds-donated-to-charity) stakes, there is an open bet between the British astrophysicist Martin Rees, a noted worrier over apocalyptic possibilities, and Harvard University’s Steven Pinker, famous for his vaulting optimism. For Rees to win, the following prediction must be vindicated: “A bioterror or bioerror will lead to one million casualties in a single event within a six-month period starting no later than Dec 31 2020.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cookout Season Is Here!
description: Uncover the grill and dust off the picnic table.
content: The long weekend is upon us, and cookout planning is in full swing by the looks of this week’s most popular New York Times Cooking recipes. What’s on your menu? Maybe Kay Chun’s Korean cheeseburgers will appear, alongside a bowl of Ali Slagle’s tahini-Parmesan pasta salad. Or Melissa Clark’s grilled merguez and onions with mint-lemon couscous, supported by Lidey Heuck’s chickpea salad (above). No matter what you choose, one thing’s for certain: It’ll taste best outside, perhaps in a park, with a cold beer or lemonade in hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Win a Bidding War Before It Starts
description: A raging seller’s market has made it harder than ever to buy the home you want. But there are ways to sweeten your offer before another buyer swoops in.
content: Q: My wife and I are trying to buy a house in Fairfield County, Conn., and we keep losing bidding wars. We offer over the asking price, but we can’t pay in cash. How much do we need to offer to get a house? Is there a magic number, or is this a pipe dream and we’ll never find one?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty and Ben Casselman
title: House Hunters Are Leaving the City, and Builders Can’t Keep Up
description: For years, people most wanted to live in places where it was the hardest to build. Now, with a rise in remote work, exurban areas look more appealing.
content: LATHROP, Calif. — They had a down payment. They were prequalified for a mortgage. They were willing to move almost an hour’s drive eastward. But the number that really mattered was “32.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: The ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ Author Finishes What She Started (and Restarted)
description: E L James, whose new book, “Freed,” continues the “Fifty Shades” story from the man’s perspective, talks about spicy romances, joining Clubhouse and reconnecting with Christian and Anastasia.
content: For a novelist who became famous writing hard-core erotica, E L James is surprisingly introverted. “I’m incredibly shy under all of it,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Biden Finds Fossil Fuels Hard to Quit
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 29, 2021.
content: “I get that they’re being pressured politically. I get that there are thin margins. But the climate crisis doesn’t care about any of that stuff.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: As G.O.P. Blocks Inquiry, Questions on Jan. 6 Attack May Go Unanswered
description: The demise of an independent panel to investigate the riot means that the country is unlikely to get a definitive accounting for one of the most serious domestic attacks on the government in history.
content: WASHINGTON — In blocking the formation of an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, Republicans in Congress have all but closed off the possibility of a full and impartial accounting for one of the most serious assaults on American democracy in history, leaving unanswered critical questions with broad implications for politics, security and public trust.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pep Guardiola hasn’t been to the final in a decade. Really.
description: Chelsea Manager Thomas Tuchel was in the Champions League final last season, when he coached Paris St.-Germain. His center back Thiago Silva started for him that day.
content: Chelsea Manager Thomas Tuchel was in the Champions League final last season, when he coached Paris St.-Germain. His center back Thiago Silva started for him that day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Low-Key
description: Adam Aaronson sneaks up on us with a subtly strenuous Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There’s a lot of cinematic action in this grid, which is Adam Aaronson’s third puzzle and his third tricky Saturday for The Times. (His most recent one was with Paolo Pasco, the KRZYZEWSKI/KYRGYZSTAN construction from last summer.) Mr. Aaronson writes in his notes that he’s a debut treasure hunter, and there are nine new entries today, including a few surprises, but there’s nothing forced or flashy about today’s solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Efforts to Advance Racial Equity Baked In Throughout Biden’s Budget
description: The budget, which was released on Friday, includes tens of billions of dollars worth of programs intended to bolster the fortunes of people of color and other historically underserved groups.
content: WASHINGTON — Six days after his inauguration, President Biden vowed that his administration would see everything through the lens of racial equality, making it “the business of the whole of government.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Walker
title: How to Take a Break
description: Developing a “rest ethic” can make work time more productive.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Anna Maria Antoinette D'Addario
title: Plague of Mice in Australia Overruns Farms, Shops and Bedrooms
description: For half a year, the rodents have been chewing their way around the country’s eastern grain belt, leaving economic and psychological scars.
content: TOTTENHAM, Australia — The stench hits you first, pungent, musty and rotting. Then you hear them: a sound like ocean waves, or pouring rain hitting concrete. And the occasional squeak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Ex-Commish With the Dish
description: America's top cop on better policing, race relations, Chauvin, Biden, Rudy and Andrew.
content: Cops have never been so blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Working Less Is a Matter of Life and Death
description: Putting limits on labor isn’t just a perk. It's a way to safeguard workers' health.
content: Search online “work too much” and you’ll get screenfuls of information about the harmful medical, mental and social consequences of spending too much time on the job, going all the way back to that old saw first recorded in the 17th century, “All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Anton Troianovski
title: Secret Chats Show How Cybergang Became a Ransomware Powerhouse
description: As the ransomware industry exploded, a Russian-speaking outfit called DarkSide offered would-be computer crooks not just the tools, but also customer support. We got an inside look.
content: MOSCOW — Just weeks before the ransomware gang known as DarkSide attacked the owner of a major American pipeline, disrupting gasoline and jet fuel deliveries up and down the East Coast of the United States, the group was turning the screws on a small, family-owned publisher based in the American Midwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Postal Service, Facing Steep Losses, Seeks to Increase Prices
description: Under the proposal, the price of a first-class stamp would increase for the first time since January 2019, to 58 cents from 55 cents.
content: Americans would have to pay more to mail a letter under a series of price increases that the Postal Service proposed on Friday as part of a plan intended to reverse $160 billion in projected operating losses over the next decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: 14 Excerpts from Commencement Speeches Without the Word C*vid
description: (And only Dr. Fauci gets to say “p*ndemic,” because he’s Dr. Fauci.)
content: Commencement speeches can bleed together. Adversity: overcome. Mountains: climbed. Friendships: lifelong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Their Olympics Are Already Canceled
description: The collapse of the pin trading market will hardly register amid the more than $15 billion cost of the Tokyo Games, but for avid traders, it’s a huge letdown.
content: A few years ago, Bud Kling had three rooms added to his house in the Pacific Palisades in California. The builders used extra concrete along with a reinforcing metal beam — and not because Mr. Kling was expecting a crowd. The rooms weren’t for people. They were designed to house and showcase his 30,000-strong collection of Olympic pins, the colorful and endlessly varied souvenirs that have been bought and traded at the Games for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Flaherty
title: Gavin MacLeod, ‘Mary Tyler Moore’ and ‘Love Boat’ Actor, Dies at 90
description: After years as a journeyman with a long list of credits but little name recognition, he found stardom on two of the biggest television hits of the 1970s and ’80s.
content: Gavin MacLeod, who tasted stardom after years as a journeyman actor when he landed roles on two of the most successful television series of the 1970s and ’80s — as the news writer Murray Slaughter on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and Capt. Merrill Stubing on “The Love Boat” — died on Saturday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: ‘If You Would Go Out on a Limb for Us, It Might Just Save Our Lives’
description: Many Americans  may never fully recover from the pandemic even if they didn’t contract the coronavirus.
content: YAMHILL, Ore. — As more vaccinated Americans emerge, blinking, to survey our post-apocalyptic world, it’s becoming increasingly clear that many of our fellow citizens may never fully recover — even if they didn’t actually contract the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: At the Indianapolis 500, Scott Dixon Has the Pole Position. And More.
description: At 40, Dixon has won six IndyCar Series titles but just one Indianapolis 500, back in 2008. “This is our year,” says the person many consider Dixon’s secret weapon.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Long before Scott Dixon became one of the most successful racecar drivers in history, winning six IndyCar Series championships and 51 races in a span of nearly two decades, he relied on his natural talent to get ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Unleashed but (Mostly) Masked, British Tourists Return to Portugal
description: Sorely in need of sun and a change of scene, British travelers returned to the newly “green-listed” country and were met by relief, exasperation — and hardly anyone.
content: After enduring a winter of strict lockdown, and a spring that saw a gradual reopening but lousy weather to spend it in, the first British tourists to Portugal since the country was “green-listed” for quarantine-free travel were elated by the thrill of escape, even if their trips were not quite as carefree as in past summers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: As the Hamptons Booms, a New World of Luxury Problems
description: Ragers on the beach. Art galleries on Main Street. Reservations disappearing. Who remembers the pandemic?
content: It was 4 p.m. last Friday and a 30-something New Yorker who’d just flown into the East Hampton airport was seated on a bench outside the terminal, typing into his laptop, a pair of orange Hermes bags to his side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Yankees Fall to Tigers in Extra Innings
description: With Aroldis Chapman limited to one inning, the Yankees lost with Justin Wilson on the mound. The Mets postponed their game.
content: DETROIT — Robbie Grossman hit a two-run homer in the bottom of the 10th inning to give the Detroit Tigers a 3-2 victory over the Yankees on Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: A Chinese city locks down a neighborhood after a flare-up worries officials.
description: Residents of five streets of a district in the southern city of Guangzhou are under stay-at-home orders after an outbreak that appeared to have spread from a restaurant.
content: Officials in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou ordered a neighborhood to lock down over the weekend, closing schools and banning dining in restaurants while they try to contain a cluster of coronavirus cases that appeared to have spread from a dim sum restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Sedona Prince Has a Message for You
description: Prince exposed inequities in college basketball with a video of the facilities at the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament. There’s more she wants you to know.
content: When Sedona Prince arrived in San Antonio in March for her first N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament, she was grateful just to be playing again after a long recovery from an injury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Michael Levenson
title: 2 Airlines Will Postpone Serving Alcohol Amid Surge of In-Flight Violence
description: American and Southwest announced the policies after the latest assault was captured on a widely watched video that showed a woman punching a flight attendant in the face.
content: Two major airlines, American and Southwest, have postponed plans to resume serving alcohol on flights in an effort to stop a surge of unruly and sometimes violent behavior by passengers who have shoved, struck and yelled at flight attendants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MJ Franklin
title: 10 Y.A. Books to Add to Your Reading List This Summer
description: From high school thrillers to fairy tale retellings, here are 10 Y.A. books you won’t want to miss this season.
content: ‘Ace of Spades,’ by Faridah Abike-Iyimide (Feiwel & Friends, June 1)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Week of Big Blows for Big Oil
description: Two victories by environmental activists added to the uncertainty surrounding the industry and Canada’s oil sands.
content: For environmentalists, it was a week of victories. For the oil and gas companies they vanquished, as well as Alberta and the other parts of Canada that rely on the energy industry, the week brought new uncertainties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: John Davis, a Voice Behind Milli Vanilli, Dies at 66
description: The singer was one of the voices behind the pop duo Milli Vanilli, fronted by Fabrice Morvan and Rob Pilatus, who later admitted that they did not sing on their albums or in concert.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Secret Recipe for All-Fun Parenting
description: It’s called being an uncle or aunt. I recommend it.
content: Frank Bruni will stop writing regular Opinion columns in late June, but his popular weekly newsletter will live on. To keep up with his political analysis, cultural commentary and personal reflections, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Chi Modu, Photographer Who Defined 1990s Hip-Hop, Dies at 54
description: His images of the Notorious B.I.G., Tupac Shakur, Dr. Dre and many more helped shape rap music’s visual identity.
content: The Notorious B.I.G., stoic and resplendent in front of the twin towers. Tupac Shakur, eyes closed and arms in the air, tendrils of smoke wafting up from his lips. Eazy-E, perched atop his lowrider, using it as a throne. Mobb Deep, huddled with friends on the rooftop of a Queensbridge housing project. Nas, reflective in his childhood bedroom. Members of the Wu-Tang Clan, gathered in a circle and staring down at the camera, sharpness in their eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Talty
title: Desperately Seeking Lifeguards for Hamptons Pools
description: The shortage could mean a summer without water aerobics, lap swims and pool parties for children.
content: The email pleas began in April. “Pool lifeguard needed,” one read. A beach club offered $200 a day and a room in Southampton. Another, the Hampton Boathouses, offered to pay $2 more an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Selinger
title: Can You Hear Me Now, in the Hamptons?
description: An influx of residents during the pandemic has strained cellphone and internet signals, making a booster the new must-have accessory.
content: Taryn Lawrence, 44, a stay-at-home mother who moved to Southampton Village six years ago, has plenty to say about cellphone reception in the area — if you can hear her. “There have always been areas where you know your phone call will drop out,” she said. “But it started getting gradually worse.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Benito Skinner Is All About Drama
description: But he’s not trying to offend anyone with his celebrity impressions.
content: Benito Skinner was born and raised in Boise, Idaho, but has long felt destined for Hollywood, by way of a stint in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Facts and figures: Time, television and the teams.
description: The Champions League final offers the most storied prize in European soccer, but today’s finalists, Chelsea and Manchester City, have almost no experience in the game that awards it.
content: The Champions League final offers the most storied prize in European soccer, but today’s finalists, Chelsea and Manchester City, have almost no experience in the game that awards it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Big Setbacks Propel Oil Giants Toward a ‘Tipping Point’
description: A surprising mix of environmentalists, pension fund managers and big money investors have scored startling victories against oil and coal, opening new battle fronts in the climate fight.
content: A nun, an environmental lawyer, pension fund executives, and the world’s largest asset manager. These were among the unusual collection of rebels who claimed a series of startling victories this week against some of the world’s biggest and most influential fossil fuel companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: To Stem Suicide and Sexual Assault, the Air Force Dons Headsets
description: Officials are hoping that an immersive virtual reality experience aimed at getting airmen to intervene will succeed where years of traditional training have failed.
content: MCGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J. — The three airmen sat quietly adjusting their headsets, murmuring to their colleague, who was in distinct trouble. “Everyone goes through rough patches sometimes,” each said, a few moments apart, to the same despondent and mildly intoxicated man, whose wife recently left him and who seemed immersed in suicidal thoughts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: Where Do Ultramarathons Go From Here?
description: More than 600,000 people ran an ultramarathon in 2018, a jump of nearly 350 percent in the last decade.
content: Ultrarunning got mainstream attention this week after a disastrous 62-mile mountain race in north-central China. Freezing rain, hail and high winds descended on the runners, ill prepared in shorts and short sleeves, leaving 21 people dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Donaldson Is Credited With Baseball’s Two Millionth Run (for Now)
description: Josh Donaldson will lose the distinction when statistics from the Negro leagues become official. The Yankees lost to Detroit and the Mets beat Atlanta in a blowout.
content: In its 146th official season, Major League Baseball reached the two million-run plateau on Saturday when Josh Donaldson of the Minnesota Twins trotted home for the milestone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson Married in Stealth Ceremony, Reports Say
description: The British prime minister’s marriage to Carrie Symonds at London’s main Roman Catholic cathedral was carried out in extreme secrecy, according to news reports.
content: LONDON — Only a week ago, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain and his fiancée, Carrie Symonds, sent friends save-the-date cards for a wedding in July 2022, according to several British newspapers. But on Saturday, Mr. Johnson and Ms. Symonds were married in a stealth ceremony at Westminster Cathedral in London, according to two tabloids, The Mail on Sunday and The Sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: Eager Teens Give Needed Boost to U.S. Vaccination Campaign
description: More than 2.5 million tweens and teens have gotten their first shot, making up about a quarter of all new vaccinations in recent weeks.
content: More than 2.5 million tweens and teens have gotten their first shot, making up about a quarter of all new vaccinations in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Hundreds Protest Vaccine Passports in London
description: Demonstrators opposing coronavirus vaccines and the idea of vaccine passports gathered in central London on Saturday.
content: Demonstrators opposing coronavirus vaccines and the idea of vaccine passports gathered in central London on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Guilty Verdict in the Killing of Mollie Tibbetts
description: A jury found Cristhian Bahena Rivera guilty of first-degree murder in the death of Ms. Tibbetts, a University of Iowa student who vanished while jogging in 2018.
content: A jury found Cristhian Bahena Rivera guilty of first-degree murder in the death of Ms. Tibbetts, a University of Iowa student who vanished while jogging in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Guilty Verdict in the Killing of Mollie Tibbietts
description: A jury found Cristhian Bahena Rivera guilty of first-degree murder in the death of Ms. Tibbetts, a University of Iowa student who vanished while jogging in 2018.
content: A jury found Cristhian Bahena Rivera guilty of first-degree murder in the death of Ms. Tibbetts, a University of Iowa student who vanished while jogging in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 29, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 29, 2021.
content: An article on Tuesday about poets in Myanmar overstated what is known about the origin of lines from a poem read by Ko Khet Thi at another poet’s funeral. While he recited the poem, it is unknown if he wrote it.
source.name: The New York Times
